Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Study of Precipitation Microphysics with Multi-Frequency Polarimetric Radar Observations and Data Assimilation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Progress toward more accurate short-range quantitative precipitation forecasts (QPF) depends on optimal use of high-resolution observations within cloud-resolving numerical weather prediction (NWP) models. Among available candidate observations, those from the U.S. network of operational S-band WSR-88D radars (which are soon to be upgraded with dual-polarization capabilities) are among the richest datasets available for ingest by both operational- and research-quality models. Prior efforts by this group of investigators advanced the characterization and retrieval of microphysical precipitation particle type and size distributions using both polarimetric-radar and ground-based disdrometer data, and supported development of forward operators and ensemble-Kalman filter based assimilation capabilities for a storm-scale NWP model. Efforts under the current project will extend to include data from multi-wavelength data (including high-resolution C-band and X-band polarimetric observations) to seek further improvements of QPF and potential for severe weather threatening life and property.

The intellectual merit of this effort centers on overcoming and correcting for non-Rayleigh scattering effects present at shorter wavelengths to allow full exploitation of these additional moment data in driving more accurate NWP simulations and (ultimately) short-term forecasts.

Broader impacts of this research will occur through graduate student and postdoc training and capitalization upon an ongoing large NOAA investment in adding dual-polarization capability to the existing operational WSR-88D radar network. Direct collaboration with staff at NOAA's Radar Operations Center will facilitate integration of developed algorithms and codes into a testbed (and perhaps ultimately operational) setting, and should aid utilization of quantitative (vs. presently more qualitative) information on storm microphysical properties to the maximum extent possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project covers many activities, including the collection, processing, and analysis of disdrometer and radar data; development of forward observation operators and retrieval algorithms; improving parameterization schemes; simulating polarimetric radar signatures; and assimilating the radar data. During the project period from 1 June 2011 to 25 May 2015, we collected 43582 minutes of rain DSD data for 163 rain events. Since 2005, we have collected a total of over 100,000 minutes of rain DSDs for 348 rain events. This team also collected 1833 5-minute snow PSDs. These DSD/PSD data are posted on the internet at http://weather.ou.edu/~guzhang/page/Disdrometer_data.html. The radar and 2DVD data have been processed and analyzed to characterize precipitation physics, to develop parameterization schemes, and to develop retrieval algorithms. The project team developed algorithms to detect and mitigate ground clutter mixed with weather radar data signals in order to yield high quality radar data. Forward observation operators have been developed to establish the relation between microphysics state parameters and the PRD variables, and extended polarimetric radar observation operators to the C- and X-bands. The forward operator has been made available to the community at http://arps.ou.edu/downloadpyDualPol.html. This team is paving the foundation for the assimilation of PRD into Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) models for optimal results.

 

The above activities have resulted in 1 book chapter, 14 journal papers, and 20 conference articles/presentations. Two graduate students (B. Putnam, V. Mahale) who are finishing up their PhD, and partial support for two post-doctoral scientists for different lengths of time (Y. Jung and Qing Cao). PhD student B. Putnam applied the PRD simulations of successful EnKF assimilation and prediction results from the ARPS model with two- and three-moment microphysics schemes (Putnam et al. 2014). Ph.D. student V. Mahale carried out an observation-based study on microphysics for the 14-15 June 2011 Norman Oklahoma downburst case using PRD, which won the best student paper at an AMS Conference (Mahale et al. 2013). V. Mahale also developed a new algorithm classifying three-body-scattering echoes due to hail within convective storms (Mahale et al. 2014).
